Alkylsulfonic acid functionalized aluminoborate: A highly efficient and regioselective solid acid catalyst for ring-opening addition of epoxide under solvent-free condition Jing Yang Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Yurong Sun Investigation Data curation Yao Yang Investigation Formal analysis Wenliang Gao Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Tao Yang Writing – review & editing Project administration ⁎ College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 401331, PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 401331 PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 401331, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Functionalized solid acid material has more accessible active surface and therefore is usually considered as an important substitute for conventional liquid mineral acid. In this work, a novel alkylsulfonic acid functionalized porous aluminoborate molecular sieve (PKU-1) has been prepared through 3-step post-synthetic method, and the high-density acidic sites were tailored and comprehensively characterized by various measurements. These acidity-controllable active sites exhibit high activity and specific regioselectivity towards alcoholysis reaction for the solvent-free production of methoxyl alcohol, and turnover frequency reaches ∼1000 h–1, which is much superior to previous reports. Comprehensive characterizations indicate catalytic centers exclusively come from –SO3H acid sites, rather than other type of Brönsted or Lewis acid sites. A plausible reaction mechanism was proposed to interpret the key role of –SO3H active sites on alcoholysis reaction based on the related experimental results. This work offers a promising solution to generate the controllable acidity and provides an available candidate in the environmentally benign catalysis for selective synthesis of some value-added compounds. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Solid acid catalysis Sulfonic acid functionalization Aluminoborate Alcoholysis High regioselectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Acid catalysts are widely used for a variety of organic transformations such as transesterification, esterification, oxidation and hydrocracking reactions [1-3]. Liquid acid catalysts, such as H2SO4, HCl and HNO3, are extremely active for the reactions, but their application is limited by difficulties in separation, reactor corrosion and inability to be reused. Solid acid catalysts can effectively alleviate the above problems, but in most cases, the relative weak acidity and the low-density acid distribution restricts their applications in the field of acid catalysis [4]. Therefore, the accurate design of highly accessible solid catalysts with strong acidity is attracting significant interests in sustainable catalysis in the last few years, and some post-synthetic methods rationally introducing some necessary acid sites in the porous solid matrix have been attempted to tune their catalytic efficiency [5,6]. For example, grafting, which is one of the commonly-used surface modification bonding with some active functional groups, is gradually becoming a hot topic, largely benefiting from the precise control the overall process, as well as the good structural stabilization of matrix. The covalent bonding of acidic groups onto the solid surface can potentially offer the controllable and stable acidity, and therefore would be a major step forward [7]. Sulfonic acid groups (–SO3H) can give the stronger Brönsted acid sites and are therefore widely used in some acid-catalytic reactions [8,9]. The commonly-used sulfonic acid source is (3-mercaptopropyl) trimethoxysilane (MPTMS). After functionalized by this organic precursor, the target solid materials can introduce a thiol group (–SH), which allows the formation of –SO3H groups after the subsequent oxidation process [10]. Because of the significant advantages of high-density acid sites and easy recyclability, various sulfonic acid functionalized materials, including organometallic frameworks [11-13], metal oxides [14,15], mesoporous biocarbon [16,17], mesoporous silica [18,19] and porous polymer [20], have been developed. For example, the immobilization of alkylsulfonic acid groups onto the MCM-41 surface via a solvothermal synthesis method has been reported [21]. To strengthen the acid density of –SO3H group, one-pot preparation strategy including the successive hydrolysis, co-condensation of MPTMS and in-situ oxidation of –SH into –SO3H groups has been employed [22]. In order to demonstrate the sustainability of –SO3H groups, M. M. Fan made a comparative study on the catalytic performance of sulfonic acid functionalized materials synthesized via two different pathways, i.e. in-situ chemical grafting and the nonbonding loading method, indicating the good chemical stability of the former synthesis pathway [23]. Herein, we have designed a –SO3H group functionalized aluminoborate (PKU-1) materials with an octahedron-based porous framework, the rationale to choose PKU-1 as the matrix largely comes from its special structural features and the advantages on catalytic performance. Single crystal X-ray diffraction indicates PKU-1 framework is constructed by AlO6 octahedra via an edge-sharing connection style, affording an oversized 18-ring channels along the c-axis. To neutralize the excessive negative charge in the skeleton, three type of borates groups are connected to octahedron-based AlO6 framework by sharing vertex oxygen atoms [24]. In the previous studies, PKU-1 matrix was proved not to be an excellent solid acid catalyst because of the exclusive coordination-saturated AlO6 and the weaker Brönsted acid sites from B–OH or Al–OH groups, thus resulting into the relatively poor capacity in the acid-catalyzed reaction. In term of skeleton compatibility, however, PKU-1 has a highly tolerant framework, and the isomorphous substitution of Al3+ in PKU-1 can be readily proceeded by some heteroatom metals (i.e. Cr3+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ga3+) in a very high level. The previous reports indicated heteroatom introduction has greatly changed the inherent acidity of PKU-1, therefore resulted into the excellent catalytic performance in some redox reactions [25-27]. More than that, PKU-1 possesses a highly-ordered channel structure and a massive surficial hydroxyl groups, this trait makes PKU-1 a good candidate to immobilize the alkylsulfonic acid groups on its surface, and therefore may become an excellent carrier with variable acid sites. Based on the above structural considerations, an octahedron-based aluminoborate (PKU-1) functionalized with sulfonic acid groups (denoted as PKU-1-SO3H) has been prepared through a multi-step procedure, structural characterizations and catalytic evaluation in the ring-opening addition of epoxides with alcohols was also discussed in detail. As an important intermediate in the biomedical, chemical and agricultural fields, epoxides are susceptible to attack by nucleophilic reagents in the acidic sites to form versatile alkoxyl alcohols, which are commonly used as intermediates in the synthesis of pharmaceutical compounds, such as antitumour and immunosuppressive drugs [28,29]. To satisfy the increasingly strict environmental requirement, some solid acid materials have been attempted in this reaction and exhibited the variable catalytic activity [30-36]. Indeed, in the current case, the as-prepared PKU-1-SO3H materials have shown an extremely high catalytic efficient in the ring-opening of epoxides under solvent-free conditions, the turnover frequency (TOF) is several times compared to the previous reports. Overall, this work demonstrates the successful synthesis of sulfonic acid functionalized materials and the catalytic utilization for selective synthesis of some value-added compounds, the plausible reaction mechanism was also proposed based on the related experimental evidences, which probably provide a potential candidate in the environmentally benign catalysis and a deep understanding of alcoholysis reactions catalyzed by solid acid catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation PKU-1-SO3H was prepared through a post-synthetic method, in which, three-step preparation procedure including matrix synthesis, grafting reaction of organic precursor (MPTMS) and thiol group oxidation were performed. The as-prepared materials were denoted as PKU-1-SO3H-x according to the used dosage of MPTMS in the starting materials, and the entire process diagram was shown in Scheme 1 . For the purpose to observe the overall functionalization process, some powder XRD patterns of the functionalized materials and their corresponding refined crystal parameters were placed in the supporting information (SI). 2.1.1 Preparation of PKU-1 matrix PKU-1 matrix was prepared using the boric acid melting method described in the previous literature [24]. Typically, three starting materials, including H3BO3 (48.5 mmol), Al(NO3)3∙9H2O (2.4 mmol) and concentrated nitric acid (1 mL) were added into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and then were sealed and heated in an oven at 513 K for 72 h. After natural cooling to room temperature, the formed solid sample was washed with warm water to remove soluble impurities and a white powder was obtained. Finally, the target matrix PKU-1 was dried at 353 K for 24 h and then reserved in a desiccator for use. 2.1.2 Grafting MPTMS precursor on PKU-1 matrix The grafting process includes two steps, the hydrolysis of MPTMS precursor and then following a condensation reaction with hydroxyl groups in the PKU-1 surface. In a typical run, PKU-1 matrix (0.3 g) was first ultrasonically dispersed in the solution composed of ethanol (6 mL) and water (2 mL), the acidity of above suspension was carefully adjusted with diluted hydrochloric acid until a pH of 2 was reached. Then, 30 mg MPTMS was added in the above suspension and heated under stirring at 343 K for 12 h in an oil bath equipped with a condensation reflux device. After completing the reaction and cooling to room temperature, the solid sample was separated through centrifugation and thoroughly washed with ethanol to remove the unreacted organic precursor. Finally, the as-prepared sample was dried for use in a vacuum oven at 353 K. Similarly, changing the starting dosage of MPTMS, the as-synthesized materials with different mass fraction of MPTMS were obtained and labelled as PKU-1-SH-x% (x = 0, 10, 20, 30). 2.1.3 Oxidation of thiol group to prepare –SO3H functionalized materials The grafted thiol groups were oxidized using 10 mL of hydrogen peroxide (30wt%) at room temperature. The solid catalyst was recovered centrifugally, extensively washed with ethanol, and dried at 353 K for 12 h Finally, the finally obtained solid catalysts were denoted as PKU-1-SO3H-x% (x = 0, 10, 20, 30). 2.2 Characterizations The phase structure of the samples was identified by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). The diffraction data were collected on a PANalytical X'Pert powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) in the 2θ range of 5° to 70° with 40 kV operating voltage and 40 mA current. Le Bail fitting was performed using TOPAS software to identify phase purity and calculate crystallographic parameters. The surface morphology of the sample was observed with scanning electron microscope (SEM Quattro S) equipped with an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was performed on a FEI Talos 200S electron microscope operated at 200 kV, the elemental mapping data were collected by an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra were performed on a Nicolet iS50 type FTIR spectrophotometer to analyze the characteristic vibration of some functional groups and chemical bond with a 4 cm−1 resolution in the range of 400−4000 cm−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was conducted on a ThermoFisher ESCALAB 250Xi with a monochromatic Al X-ray source. The electron binding energy of the C 1s (284.6 eV) was used as reference for the calibration of binding energy. Thermal analysis (TGA-DTA) was used to analyze the weight loss on a Mettler-Toledo TGA instrument under a flow of air (50 mL/min) from room temperature to 1073 K with a ramping rate of 10 K/min. Elemental analysis (CHNS) was performed on Unicube elemental analyzer to determine the sulfur and carbon content. The measurement process consists of the catalytic combustion of a sample at 1423 K and the following composition analysis of the gaseous products based on differences in their thermal conductivity. Pyridine adsorption Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (Py-FTIR) was performed on a Bruker Tensor-27 to identify different type of acid sites with a scan wavelength range of 400∼4000 cm-1. Firstly, the catalyst was pretreated at 273 K under vacuum for 2 h to expose the acid sites. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, pyridine vapor was introduced in the chamber to fully adsorb in the acid sites. After degassing respectively at 373 K, 473 K and 573 K for 30 min, the final IR spectra were collected to subtract the background under above three temperatures from 1400 to 1700 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm‒1. UV–Vis spectrum was collected to monitor the proximate range of Hammett acidity function (H 0) of PKU-1-SO3H catalyst on a TU-1901 dual-beam UV–Vis spectrophotometer under room temperature. The used two Hammett indicators were Naphthyl Red (H 0 = 4.0) and Crystal Violet (H 0 = 0.8). In a typical run, 20 mg of PKU-1-SO3H-x catalyst is firstly added in 10 mL of Hammett indicators solution and keeps stirring for 2 h in a sealed vessel at room temperature. After separating the solid powder, the absorbance of the remaining clear solution was measured on a UV–vis spectrophotometer, the scanning wavelength ranges from 800 to 190 nm. The amount of the –SO3H group in the PKU-1 matrix was estimated using the acid-base titration method. Specifically, 50 mg PKU-1-SO3H-x catalyst was added into a 10 mL KCl solution (2 M), then was kept vigorous stirring at room temperature for 24 h to give enough ion exchange between H+ and K+. After removing the solid catalyst, the remaining clear liquor was titrated with 0.01 M NaOH standard solution against phenolphthalein reagent as indicator until the color of solution turned red. The amount of acid sites was calculated based on the consumed NaOH. 2.3 Catalytic performance The ring-opening reactions of epoxides with alcohols were investigated to evaluate the catalytic performance of the PKU-1-SO3H. As a representative, styrene oxide and methanol were employed as two model substrates, and reaction equation is shown in Scheme 2 . In a typical run, styrene oxide (2 mmol), methanol (25 mmol) and PKU-1-SO3H catalyst (20 mg) were added to a round-bottomed flask and heated with stirring at 308 K in a temperature-controlled silicone oil bath equipped with a water-cooled condenser. After a specific interval, solid catalyst was separated through centrifugation, and the remaining supernatant was used to have a component analysis on a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). GC–MS analysis was performed on an Agilent 7000E gas chromatograph and a mass spectrum system to identify the molecular structure of obtained products. The obtained mass spectra data of all products are placed in the Supporting Information. The conversion and product selectivity were determined by the gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2010 plus) equipped with an FID detector and an AOC20i auto-injector. A capillary column (DB-17, 30 m length, 0.25 mm internal diameter, 0.25 μm film thickness) was used to separate organic component. The operating temperature at the injector port and FID detector were set at 573 K and 582 K, respectively, and a temperature programmed procedure was employed by increasing column temperature from 373 K to 533 K at a rate of 20 K/min. The conversion was calculated with the percentage of consumed epoxide, and the yield was obtained by multiplying the conversion and the product selectivity. Turnover frequency (TOF, h-1) is calculated with the division of the moles of consumed epoxide substrate by the moles of –SO3H in the catalyst (measured by CHNS analysis) and the consumed reaction time. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The structure and purity of all prepared materials were identified by powder X-ray diffraction. As a representative, the XRD profiles of PKU-1 matrix, PKU-1-SH-30% and PKU-1-SO3H-30% were selected to explain the above-mentioned 3-step synthetic pathway, their corresponding purity and crystalline, as well as the refined cell parameters, were shown in Fig. 1 . For comparison purpose, the simulated XRD patterns of PKU-1 matrix was also provided in the Fig. 1a. The functionalized materials have almost same profiles as parent material PKU-1, and no impurity diffraction peaks appeared, indicating the whole grafting and oxidizing process do not change the backbone of PKU-1 matrix (Fig. 1a). The XRD data were also refined to obtain the accurate crystal parameters with Le Bail package software using PKU-1-SO3H-30% as an example, the initial cell lattice parameters and space group (R3) were employed according to the previous literatures [24], the final refined cell parameters are a = 22.05 Å, c = 7.03 Å, V = 2960 Å3 (Fig. 1b). To observe the details of the fitting curve, the partial enlargement of fitting curve was also inserted in the Fig. 1b. A good convergence can be observed and all peaks appear at the expected positions (2θ), indicating the high purity phase. Fig. 2 give the corresponding changes of vibration models in FTIR spectra of the pristine PKU-1 and its functionalized materials. Contrast to PKU-1, new peaks at 1178 cm-1 and 1220 cm-1 can be assigned to Si-O and Si-CH2 groups of PKU-1-SH after anchoring MPTMS in the PKU-1 framework [37-39]. After the oxidation of –SH to –SO3H, the characteristic peaks attributed to –SO3H groups moiety appear additionally. The new bands appeared in 997cm-1 and 1040cm-1 are referred to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of S-O, while the characteristic peaks at about 1157cm-1 and 1201cm-1 are corresponding to the asymmetric and symmetric S=O stretching vibrations in –SO3H groups [40]. In addition, the relative intensity of these characteristic peaks is also strengthened with increasing the amount of anchored MPTMS. These observations hint that –SO3H groups have been successively anchored in the backbone of PKU-1 matrix. SEM was employed to observe the morphology of these functionalized PKU-1 materials, and the elemental proportion of sulfur and silicon was measured by EDAX analysis. As shown in Fig. 3 a∼3c, the morphology looks like the rod-shaped hexagonal prism, their sizes are estimated to be several micrometers in diameter and several tens of micrometers in length. EDAX analysis shows a considerable amount of sulfur and silicon have been anchored in the PKU-1 matrix, and the measured atom ratios (n Si/n S) are about 1.2 for PKU-1-SH and 1.3 for PKU-1-SO3H. According to the molecular formula of MPTMS [(CH3O)3Si(CH2)3SH], the atom number of Si and S should be the same, the slight deviation of atomic number may result from the partial hydrolysis of MPTMS and the release of thiol groups in the reflux process. HAADF-STEM was also used to characterize the as-synthesized materials, the high-resolution images and their elemental distribution maps clearly indicate the successful functionalization with –SO3H groups (Fig. 3d-3i). Fig. 3d shows the regular rod-like morphology of PKU-1-SO3H sample, typically, some special dark spots appear uniformly on the surface of PKU-1, which may result from the post-modification grafting process. Fig. 3e-3i displays the EDX elemental mapping on a selected particle, and shows a homogeneous elemental distribution through the entire region including Al, O, B, Si and S. XPS was also employed to determine the elemental composition in the surface of PKU-1-SO3H catalyst, the bind energy of all-inclusive elements was also measured to identify their apparent valence state. XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 4 a) indicates six elements including B, Al, O, S, Si and C were detected in the surface survey, the measured atomic ratio of B and Al is about 1.97, very close to the stoichiometric ratio in the formula of PKU-1 compound [HAl3B6O12(OH)4]. In addition, the relative amount of anchored alkylsulfonic acid groups can also be estimated, the molar fraction of Si and S is about 1.2, which is similar with EDS analysis. Fig. 4b gives the binding energy of S element, the characteristic peak corresponds to the bind energy of S 2p. Referring to XPS handbook, this characteristic peak was consistent with the binding energy of sulfur (+6) in the sulfonic acid moiety. The overlapping peak resolving of S 2p was performed with deconvoluted method and was divided into two independent bands, which can be assigned as S 2p3/2 (168.3 eV) and S 2p1/2 (169.8 eV) bands [13,20]. Fig. 4c shows the characteristic peak of Si 2p band, the peak appears at 102.2 eV coincides with the binding energy of Si (+4) in some organosilicone-based compounds. In addition, other 3 elements including B, Al and O were also analyzed, their XPS peaks were given in the Figure S4 of supporting information, in which, the characteristic peaks appeared at 74.8 eV and 192.7 eV correspond to the bind energy of Al 2p (3+) and B 1s (3+). The assignment of the strong peak located at 531.8 eV is the banding energy of oxygen (–2), the further deconvolution of O 1s peak can be divided into two bands, i.e. 531.8 eV and 533.8 eV bands, which is attributable to the adsorption water and lattice oxygen. The above results indicate –SH group has been completely converted into –SO3H group, thus suggesting the surface sulfonation process is successfully fulfilled. After surface modification with sulfonic acid, it can be inferred that the thermal properties of as-synthesized PKU-1-SO3H will be greatly changed, thus thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to evaluate the thermal stability of PKU-1-SO3H catalysts, and their weight-loss curves were shown in Fig. 5 . Although bonding with solid surface, the anchored organic moiety is believed to be thermally unstable and inclined to collapse from the solid surface due to thermal decomposition under the higher temperature [41]. Therefore, the thermal mass-loss analysis of PKU-1-SO3H materials will be helpful to estimate the amount of –SO3H. As shown in Fig. 5, all materials display the similar TGA profiles, however the functionalized PKU-1-SO3H materials have the greater weight loss than PKU-1. Specifically, the total weight loss of PKU-1 matrix is 18.55%, while the functionalized PKU-1-SO3H materials exhibit the significant difference with PKU-1 parent, the weight loss gradually increases from 25.77 to 28.83% when the loaded amount of alkylsulfonic acid groups becomes larger. In generally, the weight loss can be specifically divided into two different stages. The first stage attributes from the preliminary decomposition of alkylsulfonic acid groups and the removal of the physically-adsorbed water molecules. In the second stage, the main weight loss results from the dehydration of hydroxyl group in the framework and the deep oxidation of organic moiety, therefore the main framework of PKU-1 will collapse in this stage and transfer into another phase Al4B2O9 [42]. 3.2 Acid properties measurement The Hammett acidity function (H 0) is a commonly-used parameter to characterize the acid intensity of high concentration of acids [43]. H 0 can be expressed with the following formula: (1) H 0 = p K H B + + lg [ B ] [ H B + ] Here, ‘B’ represents the used base indicator, “HB+” is the protonated base indicator; [B] and [HB+] are the molar concentration of the acid-base pairs in the solution, pK HB + is the negative logarithm of the dissociation constant of HB+, the specific value of [B]/[HB+] can be calculated from the maximum absorption peak measured on UV–Vis spectrum [44,45]. In some cases, when the basic indicator was used to trap the dissociative proton, the absorbance of base indicator will gradually weaken, while the peak intensity of pronated species will strength. In the present case, the used base indicator was naphthyl red (H 0 = 0.8) and its relative intensity and the corresponding protonic form were measured spectrophotometrically in the visible spectral range. As showed in Fig. 6 , the strongest absorbance of base indicator in methanol solution was observed at 439 nm. After adding sequentially PKU-1-SO3H-x catalysts into the above indicator solution, the peak intensity at 439 nm has an increasing extinction in sequence from PKU-1 to PKU-1-SO3H-30%, and a cumulative peak intensity of the corresponding protonated pair appears simultaneously at 535 nm, hinting the amount of grafted –SO3H groups has a considerable growth in these PKU-1-SO3H-x. Nevertheless, when another weak base indicator of crystal violet (H 0 = 4.0) was employed, there is no significant color change after adding PKU-1-SO3H into the above solution, indicating Hammett acidity function H 0 of PKU-1-SO3H-x lies approximately between 0.8 and 4.0. In addition to UV–vis spectrophotometer, other two measurements, i.e. elemental analysis and acid-base titration [46,47], were also employed to estimate the anchored acid amounts in the functionalized PKU-1 surface, and the obtained results were shown in Table 1 . As for elemental analysis, the mass fraction of S element is expected to increase along with the increase of x in the PKU-1-SO3H-x, and their calculated molar ratio (n C:n S) lie in the range of 2.50 and 3.26, which is very close to the theoretical value of 3. If measured by the amount of –SO3H groups, the actual grafted –SO3H in PKU-1 can be rationally calculated and the results were also listed in Table 1. As a control, the grafted –SO3H groups are also estimated by the acid-base titration method, and the measured acid content was also contrastively listed in the Table 1, which shows a very close results between them, firmly evidencing the effective immobilization of sulfonic acid groups in the solid surface of PKU-1. 3.3 Catalytic performance From the above discussion, many characterizations have indicated –SO3H groups have grafted in the framework of PKU-1 matrix, and the functionalized PKU-1-SO3H has the richer acidic sites and is likely to be a potential candidate to activate some acid-sensitive catalytic reactions. Herein, the acid-catalyzed ring-opening reactions of epoxides were employed to evaluate the catalytic performance of PKU-1-SO3H, and methanol were used as representative nucleophilic reagents in this alcoholysis reaction. Theoretically, in the present reaction conditions, two type of isomers product, i.e. α-methoxy alcohol and β-methoxy alcohol, can be produced simultaneously. GC–MS technique was employed to qualitatively identify their molecular structure, and the relevant mass spectra are presented in SI materials (Figure S5-S6). Despite the very similar molecular structure, GC analysis indicates these two isomers can been well separated in the capillary column, and β-methoxy alcohol product is the main product and has a high selectivity, while the concentration of another isomer product is very low. Firstly, catalytic alcoholysis reaction was performed in the presence of different solid acid materials, and the corresponding catalytic results were shown in Fig. 7 (a). When PKU-1 matrix was used, the conversion is nearly zero, and no target product was obtained. Similarly, when using the unoxidized PKU-1-SH material, catalytic efficiency is also very limited and the conversion is only 6%. The poor conversion suggests the indispensability of –SO3H group on the enhancement for alcoholysis reaction. In the presence of PKU-1-SO3H, the conversion undergoes a sharp raise along with the increase of the loaded –SO3H groups, and a high conversion of ∼93% was achieved in a very short period (∼5 min). Despite the different acid amount, all PKU-1-SO3H-x samples exhibit a high catalytic efficiency and their turn-over frequency (TOF) maintain a considerable level of ∼1000 h-1, which is much higher than the previous reports, and the corresponding comparative results are listed in the Table S1 of SI. Secondly, the catalytic activity influenced by the different molar ratio of two substrates was also investigated. As a nucleophilic reagent, methanol can attack epoxide to break the C–O bond in three-membered heterocycle to form a stable addition compound, and the higher concentration of methanol is expected to forward alcoholysis reaction. Fig. 7(b) gives the catalytic results by varying the molar ratio of two reactants (i.e. n(methanol)/n(epoxide) = 1.2, 3, 12.5), it displays alcoholysis reaction is greatly accelerated as methanol proportion increases, TOF reaches a high value of 974 h–1 as n(methanol)/n(epoxide) equals to 12.5, which is nearly double higher than that using n(methanol)/n(epoxide) = 1.2. The reaction scope also was extended to other epoxides and alcohols in the presence of PKU-1-SO3H-30% catalyst, the used alcohols are methanol, ethanol, n-propanol, isopropanol, n-butanol and cyclohexanol, while the selected epoxide includes styrene oxide, cyclohexene oxide, propylene oxide and epoxy chloropropane. Likewise, the obtained methoxy alcohol products have two type of isomers, their molecular structures are also identified using GC–MS measurement and their MS spectra are listed from Figure S7 to S19 in SI materials. As summarized in Table 2 , PKU-1-SO3H-30% exhibits the better activity in these catalytic systems, most reactions have the high regioselectivity and the products are mainly β-methoxy alcohols as using larger molecule of styrene oxide. The reactivity between styrene oxide and methanol is much higher than using other epoxides, the probable reason is that the formed carbon positive ion intermediates are easily stabilized by the aromatic ring resonance, and are highly susceptible to nucleophilic attack [40]. However, when small-volume epoxides such as propylene oxide or epoxy chloropropane was employed, product selectivity has a significant change. For the former, the obtained products are the mixture of β-methoxy alcohol and α-methoxy alcohol, probably due to the preferable nucleophilic attacks on different sites of the propylene oxide by methanol to form two different products with comparable regioselectivity [13]. However, α-methoxy alcohol was mainly achieved in the latter reaction. Opposite to styrene oxide, the strong electron-withdrawing property in epoxy chloropropane has greatly changed the regioselectivity in the ring-opening of epoxide, as well as a much lower catalytic efficiency than using styrene oxide [48]. As discussed above, acting as the nucleophilic agent, the type of used alcohols has an important influence on the catalytic activity. If plotting TOF against pKa of the used alcohols, there shows a close relationship between them. As shown in Fig. 8 , methanol, although having the simplest molecular structure, exhibits the highest reaction rate, and TOF is nearly several to ten times more than that using other alcohols. With the increase of pKa value of the used alcohols, TOF has a rapid decline, the lower pKa means this alcohol is likely to form alkoxy groups with negative charge, and therefore can easily attack the formed carbocation intermediates during the nucleophilic addition reactions. If the larger-volume alcohols were used, for example cyclohexanol molecule, catalytic rate will become even slower. TOF has decreased by 23 times as using cyclohexanol substrate, and the sharp decline in catalytic activity seems likely to be the steric hindrance effect caused by the heavier 6-numbered ring moiety. 3.4 Identification of active sites As proved above, the alcoholysis reaction between styrene oxide and methanol was greatly accelerated in the presence of PKU-1-SO3H catalyst, the acid center are undoubtedly the active sites to catalyze epoxide ring-opening reaction. However, it is still necessary to identify which type of acid sites is truly effective in the catalytic reaction. Pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-FTIR) is an effective approach to distinguish Brönsted and Lewis acid sites. As a popular basic molecule, pyridine can selectively adsorb on the different acidic sites to form pyridinium ion or a coordinately bonded complex, therefore gives some characteristic peaks at different wavenumber. Fig. 9 gives the FTIR spectra of pyridine absorbed on PKU-1-SO3H-10% catalyst, five distinguishable absorption peaks including 1445, 1490, 1546, 1579 and 1596 cm-1 were clearly observed. Specially, two strong absorption peaks around at 1445 and 1596 cm-1 are assigned to Lewis acid sites adsorption, the peak near 1490 cm-1 is attributed to pyridine adsorption on Lewis and/or Brönsted acid sites (B+L), while the shoulder peaks at 1579 cm-1 is characteristic of the hydrogen-bonded pyridine [49,50]. In addition, a peak centered at 1546 cm-1, which belongs to the characteristic chemisorption of pyridine on Brönsted acid site, is obviously observed in Py-FTIR spectrum. This result is very different with the previously-reported ones measured on PKU-1 matrix, in which, only a very weak signal is present at this position [27]. The above in-situ Py-FTIR measurement indicates such an alkylsulfonic acid functionalization process has greatly changed the surface property, both Brönsted acid and Lewis acid sites have been tuned in the surface of PKU-1-SO3H materials due to the successful immobilization of sulfonic acid groups. Generally, the relative proportion of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites (B/L) can be approximately calculated with the area ratio of two peaks at 1546 cm–1 and 1445 cm–1. As for PKU-1-SO3H-10% materials, the B/L ratio are measured to be 0.43 under the lower outgas temperature of 373 K, which is far different from the measured B/L result on the PKU-1 catalyst (∼0.22) [27]. From the structural perspective, PKU-1 theoretically possess a considerable number of Brönsted acid sites due to a massive B–OH groups in their backbone. Unfortunately, these B–OH groups are too weak to bonding with pyridine molecules. In other words, these B–OH groups cannot be effectively dissociated into reactive H+ sites. As a stark contrast, after a post-modification sulfonated process, the anchored –SO3H groups possess much higher acid strength, and these reinforced Brönsted acidic sites are covered in the surface of PKU-1 and become very reactive to our performed acid-catalyzed reactions. In addition, pyridine desorption from acid sites at high outgassing temperature was also investigated. Higher degassing temperature reflects stronger acidity, because the weakly-bonded acid-base pairs will be firstly dissociated upon increasing temperature, while the stronger ones are still preserved at higher temperature. As shown in Fig. 9, as the outgassing temperature rises from 373 to 573 K, the area of these characteristic peaks rapidly became smaller, and the B/L ratio has a significant decline from 0.43 to 0.26, hinting some Brönsted acid sites are unstable and can't suffer from the higher thermal treatment. From the above discussion, PKU-1-SO3H catalyst has both Brönsted and Lewis acid sites, and the amount of Brönsted acid has greatly increased after sulfonic acid functionalization. As discussed in Fig. 7, PKU-1 matrix has exhibited no any catalytic activity, although some acid measurements such as Py-FTIR and NH3-TPD indicate PKU-1 has partly provided some weaker acid sites [25,27], hinting the intrinsic acid sites in the PKU-1 cannot effectively trigger epoxide alcoholysis. Distinguishing the actual active sites in the alcoholysis reaction is very important to understanding reaction mechanism, herein a poisoning experiment was performed to verify the actual acid sites. As well as it is known, the protons from Brönsted acid center can be replaced through ions exchange, and H+ provided by –SO3H dissociation can be exchanged with such as Na+, K+ or other cations in some neutral or alkaline solution. In this run, PKU-1-SO3H-x catalyst is added in the KOH solution and enable a full replacement between H+ and K+, then the obtained PKU-1-SO3K sample was examined with HAADF-STEM to observe the degree of ion exchange. Fig. 10 gives the element map distribution of Si, S and K element, and the EDAX analysis in Fig. 10d indicates K element is also evenly allocated through the rod-like surface of PKU-1, which also provides a direct proof of successful grafting –SO3H groups in the solid surface of PKU-1. Theoretically, the remove of H+ sites in PKU-1-SO3H is very likely to result into the catalytic deactivation to alcoholysis reaction. Based on this consideration, this exchanged PKU-1-SO3K catalyst has been employed to evaluate the catalytic efficiency, the results are shown in the Fig. 10e. As expected, PKU-1-SO3H catalyst has completely lost the original catalytic capacity after K+ exchange, and catalytic conversion almost drops zero. This phenomenon indicates catalytic sites are derived from the Brönsted acid centers –SO3H, nor the Lewis acid centers. 3.5 Reaction kinetics and catalyst stability Reaction order and the apparent activation energy (E a) are two important kinetic parameters to estimate reaction rate and further speculate reaction mechanism, therefore, these two parameters were calculated through analyzing the curves of styrene oxide conversion versus reaction time at 323K. As shown in Fig. 11 a, the curves of styrene oxide concentration versus reaction time were plotted at 324 K. Analyzing these obtained time-dependence curves, the fitting result gives a very good linear correlation between the concentration expression of ln[(a-x)/(b-x)] and the reaction time, which can be expressed as below: (2) k 2 t = 1 a − b ln b ( a − x ) a ( b − x ) Where x refers to the product concentration of β-methoxy alcohol at different moments t, a and b represent the initial concentration of methanol and epoxide. Eq. 2 obviously obeys the kinetic characteristics of the total second-order reaction, among which, the order of two reactants are 1 respectively. In a similar way, the corresponding reaction rate constants k at different temperature T can also be determined through the linear fitting according to Eq. 2, the function relation between 1/T and the corresponding lnk at different temperature are shown in Fig. 11b. After a linear regression, the apparent activation energy E a can be deduced to be about 54 kJ/mol from the slope of the fitting curve according to Arrhenius empirical formula. The lower apparent activation energy E a suggests PKU-1-SO3H-30% catalyst can efficiently activate the involved substrate molecules and improve the reaction rates in epoxide alcoholysis reaction. Catalyst stability has a great influence on industrial application, herein, the reusability of PKU-1-SO3H-30% under the similar reaction condition was investigated. The heterogeneous nature of reaction system allows the quick recovery of solid catalyst from the solution. After completing each reaction, the powdered catalyst was separated by centrifugation, followed by a solvent-washing and a subsequent drying procedure. Despite a slight loss of catalyst weight, the next round was continued without adding any fresh catalyst. Fig. 12 gives the recyclability of PKU-1-SO3H-30% catalyst, and the result reveals that nearly 90% activity is still maintaining after 5 successive runs. In fact, the partial loss of acid sites is very common for –SO3H functionalized materials after some batches of alcoholysis, the reasons may come from the poisoning of the active sites by some alkaline molecules, or the loss of –SO3H groups in the alcoholysis reaction, especially using highly polar solvents [51,52]. Powder XRD profiles shows that the framework structure of PKU-1-SO3H-30% remains unchanged after 5 batches alcoholysis, and no significant change of catalyst crystallinity was observed, evidencing the framework stability of PKU-1-SO3H-30% materials. As discussed above, catalytic activity has a slight loss after 5 runs, and the conversion reduces from 99% to 87%. To deeply understand the possible deactivation mechanism, the recycled catalyst was characterized with py-FTIR and TEM to assess the status of alkylsulfonic acid groups, and the obtained results are showed in Fig. 13 . Fig. 13b-13f displays the EDX elemental mapping on a selected particle, all elements have a homogeneous distribution through the entire region. Both S and Si element maps give the clear signals, hinting a homogeneous and high element content in the surface. TEM analysis indicates the surface of PKU-1-SO3H remains the good coverage with alkylsulfonic acid, and active substance has not suffered from the great loss after 5 times cycles. Pyridine adsorbed FTIR spectrum (Fig. 13h) was used to indicate the change of Brönsted acid amount, all characteristic peaks belonging to Brönsted acid remains the same with the fresh catalyst. However, judged from the relative proportion of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites (B/L) appeared at 1546 cm–1 and 1445 cm–1 at 373 K, the approximately calculated B/L is about 0.32, which is lower than fresh catalyst (B/L=0.43, see Fig. 9 in the manuscript). The change of acidic amount suggests a partial damage of Brönsted acid centers in the alcoholysis reaction, thus results into a loss of catalytic efficiency. Therefore, catalyst stability still requires more attention in the subsequent research. 3.6 Possible catalytic mechanism From the above discussion, the anchored –SO3H groups was evidenced to be active centers and played a critical role on the ring-opening reaction between epoxide and alcohols. Generally, the acid-catalyzed ring-opening alcoholysis reactions have been widely investigated, and the related catalytic mechanism was also discussed elsewhere [53]. Based on the above-mentioned experimental results and the previous reports, a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed to explain the reaction pathways for catalytic alcoholysis of epoxide in the presence of PKU-1-SO3H. It is widely recognized that the opening of epoxide ring contains two steps, i.e. the addition of a proton to 3-ring oxygen of epoxide and followed the deprotonated molecules of the substrate to one of the carbon atoms of oxirane ring [40,54]. If catalyzed in acidic sites, the nucleophilic addition is greatly enhanced through the reversible formation of more reactive conjugate acid of the epoxide. As demonstrated in Fig. 14 , PKU-1-SO3H first provides the Brönsted acid centers to coordinate with the 3-membered oxygen ring of epoxide molecule through hydrogen bond, and subsequently increases the electrophilicity of the carbon atoms in the epoxide to form a benzylic carbocation. The next step involves the nucleophilic attack by methanol to the energy-preferable substituted carbon atom of epoxide. In our case, the formation of β-alkoxyl alcohols is more favorable, and it generally obeys SN1 nucleophilic pathway [20,47]. In other words, the more hindered carbon atom (β site) of epoxide ring is more susceptible to attacks from nucleophilic reagents to generate a stable carbocation, thus gives final β-alkoxyl alcohols after restoring PKU-1-SO3H catalyst. 4 Conclusions A novel octahedron-based aluminoborate was successfully sulfonated through a 3-step post-synthetic modification for the first time, i.e. the preparation of PKU-1 matrix, the immobilization of MPTMS in the surface of PKU-1, followed by the oxidation of thiol group to –SO3H groups. Many characterizations such as XRD, FTIR, TEM, XPS, TGA have confirmed the successful incorporation of –SO3H groups into the surface of PKU-1 matrix, and the as-prepared PKU-1-SO3H catalysts presents a high-density acid amount, determined comprehensively by Py-FTIR, UV–Vis spectra, CHNS elemental analysis, acid-base titration. The anchored amount of –SO3H can be well regulated by changing the dosage of –SO3H content in the starting materials. Acting as an excellent Brönsted acid catalyst, PKU-1-SO3H have exhibited much higher catalytic activity and stereoselectivity towards the ring-opening reaction of epoxide, and turnover frequency reaches ∼1000 h-1, which is much better than the previous reports. The reaction scope between some different substrates as well as the catalytic recycling indicated PKU-1-SO3H has a board universality and a certain degree of stability. A plausible reaction mechanism was proposed to discuss the possible catalytic pathway activated by the involved -SO3H active sites during the ring-opening of epoxide attacked by methanol. In summary, PKU-1-SO3H materials were very active and more highly efficient in the nucleophilic addition of epoxide, thus making them a suitable alternative in mineral acid catalysis and promoting the development of fine chemicals in the environmentally benign catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Functionalized solid acid material has more accessible active surface and therefore is usually considered as an important substitute for conventional liquid mineral acid. In this work, a novel alkylsulfonic acid functionalized porous aluminoborate molecular sieve (PKU-1) has been prepared through 3-step post-synthetic method, and the high-density acidic sites were tailored and comprehensively characterized by various measurements. These acidity-controllable active sites exhibit high activity and specific regioselectivity towards alcoholysis reaction for the solvent-free production of methoxyl alcohol, and turnover frequency reaches ∼1000 h–1, which is much superior to previous reports. Comprehensive characterizations indicate catalytic centers exclusively come from –SO3H acid sites, rather than other type of Brönsted or Lewis acid sites. A plausible reaction mechanism was proposed to interpret the key role of –SO3H active sites on alcoholysis reaction based on the related experimental results. This work offers a promising solution to generate the controllable acidity and provides an available candidate in the environmentally benign catalysis for selective synthesis of some value-added compounds.
